FacilityName: Koch Nitrogen Company - Aurora Terminal WT-12

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
KOCH NITROGEN COMPANY

Aurora Terminal WT-12
Aurora, Nebraska

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)


Introduction and Policies

Koch Nitrogen Company (KNC) is committed to being associated with unmatched environmental performance as measured by its employees, customers, regulators, and the public.  KNC?s management philosophy goals are achieved by the personal commitments of employees and contractors and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the terminal, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the 5 year accident history of the terminal and planned changes to improve safety at the terminal.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Aurora Terminal is one of many facilities owned and operated by KNC along a 2,000-mile pipeline supplying anhydrous ammonia to the Midwest corn belt where it is used primarily as a fertilizer.  At the terminal, anhydrous ammonia is delivered by pipeline and stored until it is loaded on to trucks for distribution.  

Anhydrous ammonia is the only toxic substance regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP) that is present at the Aurora Terminal in amounts above threshold quantity.  The terminal is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation. 


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by KNC.  These high standards are achieved by:

?Operating in compliance with all required environmental permits and regulations. 
?Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that any release will be unintentional and acknowledged as unacceptable.
?Correcting any non-compliance found during regular audits of the facility.
?Reporting promptly to reg

ulators any non-compliance found during the course of audits as required by law. 
 
Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

Worst Case Release Scenario
As defined by the U. S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP Regulations, the worst case release scenario is ?? the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint??.  In the case of the Aurora Terminal, this would involve a 30,000-ton refrigerated ammonia storage tank, administratively controlled to a maximum fill capacity of 26,800 tons. Using the EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) methods, the distance ammonia vapors could travel in this hypothetical case would result in offsite impacts.  If such an incident occurred, an earthen dike that surrounds the storage tank would largely contain the liquid ammonia. 

Alternative Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario, characterized as a more likely scenario that could involve an offsite exposure to ammonia vapors, is the overfilling of the ammonia bullet tank as product is being delivered by pipeline to the facility.  Using the EPA OCA methods, the distance that ammonia vapors could travel in this case would result in offsite impacts.  If such an incident occurred, relief valves on top of the bullet would be activated during the filling process.  These valves ensure that the entire bullet does not rupture.

There are several active mitigation measures in place, which substantially reduce the chance that such an event could occur.  The level of liquid ammonia in the bullet is monitored on a continuous basis.  If this level becomes too high, a motor-operated valve on the inlet pipe to the bullet will close automatically.  If higher levels are then detected in the bullet, an additional reverse check valve will automatically close on the inlet pipe and will alarm through the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) monitoring system in Wichita,

Kansas.  Following receipt of the alarm, the dispatcher calls out the terminal manager or terminal personnel to respond to the alarm, determine the cause and take appropriate action.  High pressure in the ammonia storage bullet will similarly result in this check valve closing and activation of SCADA.  These active mitigation measures serve to either prevent this scenario from occurring or to minimize the impact if it does occur.

These potential ammonia releases have been communicated to the terminal employees and to local emergency response officials in Hamilton County.


Prevention Program

The Aurora Terminal has been operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program since 1992.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees and constant emphasis on safety have helped avoid any serious accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

?Requiring trucks to have a brake interlock system that helps prevent a truck driver from driving away before the transfer hose is properly disconnected.
?Ensuring no interruption in the combustion of ammonia vapors by having continuous pilots in the flares.
?Providing annual truck loading training to ensure driver safety. 

These safeguards as well as the vigilance of KNC?s trained employees have helped the facility operate safely since it was acquired in 1988.


Five Year Accident History

In the past five years, there has been only one incident at the Aurora terminal that would qualify as an RMP accident.  The incident involved a truck driver being burned by anhydrous ammonia due to not properly following truck-loading procedures.  The driver received medical treatment for the burns and was released.  Driver training and writte

n procedures are in place to prevent this type of accident from reoccurring.  There were no other injuries or offsite impacts from this incident.

Emergency Response Program

The terminal will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the Aurora Terminal with the Hamilton County Fire Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Hamilton County Sheriff and, as appropriate, Memorial Hospital located in Aurora, the Utility Company, the Local Emergency Planning Committee, and the Nebraska State Highway Patrol.  The Aurora Terminal Manager is responsible for coordinating all emergency actions.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the terminal is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program forms the framework on which the level of safety at the Aurora Terminal will continue to improve.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

?The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
?The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
?The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.
?Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the terminal is constantly being evaluated for improvements.
?An ongoing di

alogue with the Hamilton County Emergency Management Director or his designate will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops. 

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Hamilton County Emergency Management Director for the latest information on emergency response for the county.  The terminal plans to coordinate its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.
